text: <https://benjamin.computer/posts/2020-12-12-rust-python.html>

attachments.title: Rust, Python and Fish
attachments.text: Benjamin Blundell, benjamin.computer. I make things with computers

text: What a last line. On a completely different note, I think rust is a hard sell to people, its not the easiest and the target are not scientists and researchers. I think Python is still good for the majority of people though, each niche to its own.

elements.text: What a last line. On a completely different note, I think rust is a hard sell to people, its not the easiest and the target are not scientists and researchers. I think Python is still good for the majority of people though, each niche to its own.

text: yeah, I have the same feeling: rust is great for software developers, but fairly bad for researchers

elements.text: yeah, I have the same feeling: rust is great for software developers, but fairly bad for researchers

text: I mean I gave up learning it like twice, so perhaps I am not the best to say anything about it, but I doubt I am alone in this ><

text: it's kinda hard to follow the article at all, without any code besides the "here's how I used the threadpool"

text: and I'm also not sure why they're growing the vector dynamically, isn't it possible to know the chunk size beforehand..?

text: yes, I was also looking for the full code, it's quite vague.  nice to read the experience, but it would be nicer to see what he did

text: I mean, not to bash their approach, but it really feels more like "let's see what numba can do and then what a naive parallel rust approach achieves"

text: we can't even compare the parallel versions to the regular versions..

text: interesting blog. I'm currently learning Rust now. It's a little more than tricky at first I'll say that... Pretty dang weak for computational stuff... But - it seems like it could be fleshed out a bit

elements.text: interesting blog. I'm currently learning Rust now. It's a little more than tricky at first I'll say that... Pretty dang weak for computational stuff... But - it seems like it could be fleshed out a bit

text:
>  I think this is partially because it's a hard language to learn initially and requires some knowledge of the machine, data-types, borrowing and the like. It certainly strokes your programmer ego, which isn't such a bad thing if kept in check.
This is very unappealing to me.

elements.text: I think this is partially because it's a hard language to learn initially and requires some knowledge of the machine, data-types, borrowing and the like. It certainly strokes your programmer ego, which isn't such a bad thing if kept in check.
This is very unappealing to me.

text: yea I find that statement incredibly unappealing. The community so far has been really nice and not egoistic. The reality is - there's stuff you can't do in Julia. So you have to use another language from time to time. Rust is looking like a more appealing C++.

elements.text: yea I find that statement incredibly unappealing. The community so far has been really nice and not egoistic. The reality is - there's stuff you can't do in Julia. So you have to use another language from time to time. Rust is looking like a more appealing C++.

text: That said I've sunk 3 days into Rust and I've gotten almost nowhere...

elements.text: That said I've sunk 3 days into Rust and I've gotten almost nowhere...
